citations.narrative:
The applicant is conducting activities not authorized by a Class A license. During inspection, the applicant showed
inspectors a stack of acquisition and disposition records where she is purchasing adult dogs for another licensed facility.
The applicant reports brokering activity started in July 2024 and approximately 27 dogs have been brokered. Dealers
which maintain a Class A license may only sell animals born and raised on their property. A Class B license is required for
buying and selling adult dogs not born and raised on the property. Licenses are only issued for specific activities. A new
license must be obtained prior to a change in business activities, such as brokering. Correct by ensuring a Class B license
is obtained prior to conducting brokering activity or restrict business activities to those covered under a Class A license.

The applicant is not getting health certificates for puppies prior to being transported by an intermediate handler. In 2024,
the applicant has had eleven shipments with a total of forty-five puppies being delivered by intermediate handlers, for
which none of the puppies had an accompanying health certificate. Health certificates are important to ensure that the
puppies are free from communicable and/or contagious diseases prior to shipment. Correct by ensuring that any dog or
puppy delivered to any intermediate handler for transportation in commerce is accompanied by a health certificate
executed and issued by a licensed veterinarian.

Ten enclosures in the outside portion of the sheltered housing facility each had a wooden panel (approximately 12” x 12”)
that is not impervious to moisture. The panels are bolted to the metal sidewalls of the outside runs and are used to
prevent the dogs from using the drain gutters to access adjacent enclosures. Unsealed wood is not impervious to
moisture. Moisture can cause warping and deterioration of the material, may trap odors, and cannot be appropriately
sanitized. Correct by ensuring all walls of the sheltered housing facility are impervious to moisture.

A one year old dog is not up to date on the distemper and parvovirus vaccines. Female Cavapoo “Meesha” #5712 has no
record of the distemper and parvovirus vaccines. According to the APHIS 7005 Inventory of Dogs on Hand, the applicant
obtained this dog on November 8, 2023. The Program of Vet Care prescribes for the distemper and parvovirus vaccines
to be given at 7, 11, and 15 weeks of age, and then yearly. Distemper and parvovirus are contagious viruses and may
cause stress, discomfort, or other symptoms of illness in affected dogs. Correct by ensuring vaccinations for contagious
and/or deadly diseases in dogs, including distemper and parvovirus, are done in accordance with the written Program of
Vet Care and manufacturer instructions.

There was an incomplete medical record for Molly #0611. A medical record from July 2024 lists Molly was to have
“ammox” (Amoxicillin) medication after a C-section (Caesarean section) surgery for 10 days. The record shows a list of
dates from July 17-July 26. Only July 17-July 20 are marked as being completed. The applicant reports she completed all
the doses of ammox but did not record each date of administration. It is important to maintain complete medical records
so that adequate veterinary care can be assessed. Correct by ensuring medical records are completely documented,
including the names and dates of all treatments administered.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by November 10, 2024, or the applicant will forfeit the license
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
Additional Inspectors:
Eric Irvin, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.1(b)(1) 
   
Requirements and application 
The applicant is conducting activities not authorized by a Class A license. During inspection, the applicant showed 
inspectors a stack of acquisition and disposition records where she is purchasing adult dogs for another licensed facility. 
The applicant reports brokering activity started in July 2024 and approximately 27 dogs have been brokered. Dealers 
which maintain a Class A license may only sell animals born and raised on their property. A Class B license is required for 
buying and selling adult dogs not born and raised on the property. Licenses are only issued for specific activities. A new 
license must be obtained prior to a change in business activities, such as brokering. Correct by ensuring a Class B license 
is obtained prior to conducting brokering activity or restrict business activities to those covered under a Class A license. 
2.78(a) 
   
Health certification and identification. 
The applicant is not getting health certificates for puppies prior to being transported by an intermediate handler. In 2024, 
the applicant has had eleven shipments with a total of forty-five puppies being delivered by intermediate handlers, for 
which none of the puppies had an accompanying health certificate. Health certificates are important to ensure that the 
puppies are free from communicable and/or contagious diseases prior to shipment. Correct by ensuring that any dog or 
puppy delivered to any intermediate handler for transportation in commerce is accompanied by a health certificate 
executed and issued by a licensed veterinarian. 
3.3(e)(1)(iii) 
   
Sheltered housing facilities. 
Ten enclosures in the outside portion of the sheltered housing facility each had a wooden panel (approximately 12” x 12”) 
that is not impervious to moisture. The panels are bolted to the metal sidewalls of the outside runs and are used to 
prevent the dogs from using the drain gutters to access adjacent enclosures. Unsealed wood is not impervious to 
moisture. Moisture can cause warping and deterioration of the material, may trap odors, and cannot be appropriately 
sanitized. Correct by ensuring all walls of the sheltered housing facility are impervious to moisture. 
3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs.

A one year old dog is not up to date on the distemper and parvovirus vaccines. Female Cavapoo “Meesha” #5712 has no 
record of the distemper and parvovirus vaccines. According to the APHIS 7005 Inventory of Dogs on Hand, the applicant 
obtained this dog on November 8, 2023. The Program of Vet Care prescribes for the distemper and parvovirus vaccines 
to be given at 7, 11, and 15 weeks of age, and then yearly. Distemper and parvovirus are contagious viruses and may 
cause stress, discomfort, or other symptoms of illness in affected dogs. Correct by ensuring vaccinations for contagious 
and/or deadly diseases in dogs, including distemper and parvovirus, are done in accordance with the written Program of 
Vet Care and manufacturer instructions. 
3.13(b)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
There was an incomplete medical record for Molly #0611. A medical record from July 2024 lists Molly was to have 
“ammox” (Amoxicillin) medication after a C-section (Caesarean section) surgery for 10 days. The record shows a list of 
dates from July 17-July 26. Only July 17-July 20 are marked as being completed. The applicant reports she completed all 
the doses of ammox but did not record each date of administration. It is important to maintain complete medical records 
so that adequate veterinary care can be assessed. Correct by ensuring medical records are completely documented, 
including the names and dates of all treatments administered. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by November 10, 2024, or the applicant will forfeit the license 
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Eric Irvin, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
